message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Metastatic lesions are caused by cancer cells spreading through the blood vessels, which are called hematogenous spread. Collagenase is involved in tissue remodeling, but is not a mechanism for metastasis. Transcoelomic and lymphatic spread are mechanisms for cancer spread in specific organs, but not in the case of lumbar vertebrae metastasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has lung cancer and the metastases are in the lumbar vertebrae suggests that the most likely mechanism of spread is hematogenous spread, in which cancer cells spread through the blood vessels. Collagenase can aid in cellular invasion but it does not explain the specific location of the metastases. Transcoelomic spread is more common in ovarian cancer, and lymphatic spread would lead to regional rather than distant metastases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Metastasis occurs via three main routes: hematogenous spread, lymphatic spread, and transcoelomic spread. Given the patient’s history of lung cancer and the presence of metastatic lesions in the lumbar vertebrae, the most likely mechanism is hematogenous spread.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, hematogenous spread is the most common mechanism for the development of metastatic lesions, especially in the context of lung cancer. Collagenase may aid in cellular invasion, but it is not the primary mechanism for metastasis in this case. Transcoelomic spread and lymphatic spread are more commonly associated with other types of cancer, such as ovarian and breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The metastatic lesions are in the lumbar vertebrae, which suggests that they spread through the bloodstream from the primary lung cancer. Hematogenous spread is the most common way cancer cells metastasize to the bone. Option A is related to the degradation of extracellular matrix, but it is not specific to bone metastasis. Option C is related to the spread of cancer cells between body cavities, and option D is related to the spread through lymphatic vessels, neither of which applies to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Metastatic lesions from a primary lung cancer are most commonly spread hematogenously, meaning the cancer cells travel through the bloodstream to distant sites in the body. Options A, C, and D refer to other ways cancer cells can spread, but are less likely in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of metastatic lesions in the lumbar vertebrae suggests hematogenous spread, which is a common mechanism of metastasis from lung cancer. Collagenase aids in invasion but would not directly lead to the development of metastatic lesions. Transcoelomic spread occurs in tumors of the abdominal cavity and lymphatic spread would likely first involve lymph nodes before spreading to distant sites.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The metastatic lesions are most likely due to hematogenous spread, which is when cancer cells spread through the bloodstream to other parts of the body. Collagenase and lymphatic and transcoelomic spread are all other mechanisms by which cancer can spread, but hematogenous spread is the most likely in this case given the location and nature of the metastatic lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the bone metastases are in the lumbar vertebrae suggest that the most likely mechanism for their development is hematogenous spread, where cancer cells enter the bloodstream and travel to distant sites. Collagenase, transcoelomic spread, and lymphatic spread are not commonly associated with bone metastases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that metastatic lesions are present in the lumbar vertebrae suggests hematogenous spread. Collagenase, transcoelomic spread, and lymphatic spread are mechanisms of tumor invasion and spread, but are less likely to result in metastatic lesions in bone.
